bestBHT.bht: During Jesus' arrest, a young man, possibly an attached disciple, fled from the scene in such haste that he left behind the linen cloth he was wearing, symbolizing the desperation of the moment. The vivid, lifelike detail highlights the rage of the wicked men who sought to harm those associated with Jesus. While the disciples managed to evade capture, this young man, perhaps due to his clothes or expression of sympathy, was apprehended. Mark's account reveals the intense opposition Jesus faced and emphasizes the divine power that ultimately protected his followers.

Henry Alford: The young man fled and left the linen cloth with which he was girt.
It seems to have been some attached disciple of the Lord.
The disciples were not laid hold of:—this perhaps was throwing some obstacle in the way of the removal of Jesus.
Marvin Vincent: Linen cloth [σινδονα]. The probable derivation is from jIndov, an Indian.
India being the source from which came this fine fabric used for wrapping dead bodies.
In which Christ's body was enveloped.
John Calvin: Those wicked men — as usually happens in riotous assemblies stormed and raved without shame or modesty.
We certainly perceive — as I just now said — that those wicked men raged with cruel violence.
They did not even spare a poor young man, who had left his bed, almost naked, and run, on hearing the noise.
Philip Schaff: A certain young man. Not one of the Apostles, all of whom had fled, but a disciple.
He may have been seized because of some expression of sympathy, or simply because of his strange attire.
If it was anyone well-known to the first readers of the Gospel, it was no doubt the Evangelist himself.
Archibald T. Robertson: A certain young man. This incident alone in Mark.
It is a lifelike touch quite in keeping with such a situation.
Note the vivid dramatic present κρατουσιν (they seize him).
John Gill: he had only a piece of linen wrapped about his middle, to cover his nakedness; and in this garb ran out, to see what was doing.
The design of Mark in relating this incident, is to show the rage and fury of these men; who were for sparing none that appeared to be or were thought to be the followers of Christ.
the preservation of the disciples was entirely owing to the wonderful power of Christ.
John Wesley: A young man — It does not appear, that he was one of Christ's disciples.
Probably hearing an unusual noise, he started up out of his bed, not far from the garden, and ran out with only the sheet about him, to see what was the matter.
And the young men laid hold on him — Who was only suspected to be Christ's disciple: but could not touch them who really were so.

bhtAttempts.bht: As Jesus was being arrested in the garden, a young man who was likely an attached disciple of the Lord quickly fled, leaving behind the linen cloth he was wearing. This detail, unique to the Gospel of Mark, brings a vivid and lifelike touch to the dramatic situation. The young man's hasty departure and the seizing of him by the wicked men show the rage and fury of those who sought to harm anyone associated with Jesus. It is notable that while the disciples were not apprehended, this young man was, perhaps due to his attire or some expression of sympathy. In sharing this incident, Mark emphasizes both the violent opposition Jesus faced and the preservation of his followers, which was due to the divine power of Christ.
